We were wary of driving through Death Valley because we thought there would be nothing to see. We were really impressed with the scenery and changing landscape - it is quite beautiful in a very different way than most natural things we have seen. The Point has a parking lot with rest rooms near the road and a short walk up a bit of a steep hill which provides a wide view. The steepness of the hill may give you pause if you are not in a little bit of walking shape - doable with a stroller or wheelchair if the person behind it has a little muscle. You look out to a 'sea' of undulating sand and rock in varying colors and textures that is really quite impressive, across a flat 'valley' with the mountains providing a dramatic backdrop. A few general tips for Death Valley:
- Death Valley holds the record for the highest reliably recorded air temperature in the world (134°F / 56.7°C). Therefore, make sure you have lots of food and especially water. Wear breathable clothes.
- If your car doesn't have a GPS, use real maps or offline Google maps since you won't be able to connect to the internet. We used offline Google maps.
- Bring a nice camera so you get some unforgettable photos!

We got there between 9 and 10 am and we were lucky that there was a cloud cover and the sun was just peeking out from behind the clouds illuminating Manly Beacon first, before the other areas.
